channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Attention, Perl programmers. We’re looking for those among you who loved their childhood chemistry sets and could spend hours studying their ant farms. Science buffs and genetics junkies, our client wants to hear from you. Excellent Modern Perl skills, ideally with Dancer, and at least some familiarity with JavaScript on the front-end.

item.title: Change the world without leaving your desk! Remote (or on-site) Perl role - UK, Switzerland or South
item.description: As a thriving multinational fundraising group with operations in the UK, Switzerland, USA, Canada, and South Africa, our client works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools to connect with their supporters. Along with Modern Perl, automated payment experience is a must-have.

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Our client is one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re not saying you shouldn’t spend money, but if you’re going to splash out on the latest gear, why not get the best price? Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. They’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who is comfortable with Modern Perl and Python and who is passionate about Machine Intelligence and can evaluate NLP systems.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. Not feeling the urge to commute during these socially distanced times and beyond? Not a problem. The role is 100% remote-friendly for folks in the UK.

item.title: The perils of the home-made framework
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 124
item.description: Simon keeps the discussion to the point whether it is task #1 or task #2. You should definitely take a look. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 124: War Day
item.description: By chance, I noticed the conversation betweem Roger and Cheok-Yin. It feels great to see member discussing each other's solution. Thanks Roger for sharing your experience with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 124
item.description: Interesting use of PDL for the task #1. I love when the code gets re-used. It shows they are not forgotten. Good use of existing code.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 124: difficult women
item.description: Luca used Raku class to deal with the task #1. I noticed the intensity in his work. I respect the honesty in his contributions. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 124: Happy Women Day and Tug of War
item.description: Laurent seems to be on loose this week. He gave tough fight to Abigail with his guest contributions to task #1. Having said, his Perl solution to Tug of War is something to watch out. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #124
item.description: James pushed the bar higher as far as the task #1 is concerned. For Tug of War task, he once again presented the solution with performance matrix. I simply love the matrix, it tells a nice story.

item.title: TWC 124: Literalism and existence proofs in the service of stress reduction
item.description: Jared writing is always top notch. You don't realise that you are reading technical blog but in the end you find yourself surrounded by lots technical keywords. You don't want to miss out the fun.

item.title: PWC124 - Tug of War
item.description: Keeping up the tradition, Flavio, presenting solution in Perl and Raku. I loved the reasoning behind his approach.

item.title: PWC124 - Happy Women Day
item.description: Flavio also took the task seriously and presented really cool solution.

item.title: Can't Think of a Pithy Title: Perl Weekly Challenge #124
item.description: My personal favourite is the solution to task #1. Good use of maths, loved it.

item.title: Venus in the Balance
item.description: Well, I have never seen Colin being so serious about task. I am impressed by the thought process behind the task #1. Implementation has blown me away completely. Cool implementations. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Happy Tug with Raku
item.description: The best part of the blog by Arne is that you get more than you asked for. Always full of different ideas and amazing solutions. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 124: Tug of War
item.description: As always, Abigail came up with yet another elegant and easy to follow solution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 124: Happy Women Day
item.description: Abigail tried the trivial task in many different languages.

item.title: Perl Review - The Weekly Challenge - 122
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 124
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Happy Women Day" and "Tug of War" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 125
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Pythagorean Triples" and "Binary Tree Diameter". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: 5 programming languages to learn in 2021
item.description: Interesting discussion putting Perl at number 5 in the list.

item.title: Railroad diagrams for SQL 2003 and SQL 2016
item.description: Ron started the discussion to find out if there is any Perl code which converts a grammar into a railroad diagram?

item.title: Why am I giving up on Perl?
item.description: Sebastien trying to justify his reason behind giving up on Perl.

item.title: Think Bayes
item.description: Well, in the blog, Flavio promoting a book, Think Bayes, that he is reading at the moment. Nice introduction, I must say. Bookmarking it for later reading.

item.title: What’s Next for Object-Oriented Perl?
item.description: Promoting Object::Pad by upgrading his existing code. Interesting discussion with regard to the issues faced during the process.

item.title: Board review: Community Affairs Team
item.description: TPF board has chosen to put the CAT on hiatus while its charter is formalized, and is retracting the public announcements of previous investigations.

item.title: #524 - Object::Pad
item.description:
Hi there

It is no longer secret anymore that I am the biggest fan of the project, Corinna, headed by Curtis Poe. The motto of the project tells everything about it, "Good enough" is not good enough. Having said that we still have to wait for the final push by the team behind the project.

What shall we do in the meantime?

Well, we are encouraged to give a try, Object::Pad. Paul Evans is the man behind this distribution. A fellow member of Team PWC, Cheok-Yin Fung, wrote a blog, OO linked lists in Perl, last year (25th Sep 2020 to be precise). She updated the very same blog recently and added one more implementation using Object::Pad, this time. This is what I call serious hacking. I have one more similar story to share with you as shared in the blog by Mark Gardner. In the blog, Mark, shared his experience dealing with Object::Pad. With so much going on about Object::Pad, I gave myself a week time to get things in place. But the week gone without any result unfortunately. Don't get me wrong, I am not giving up yet. I will get my hand dirty and share my experience with everyone. In fact, Dave Cross, suggested I should include Object::Pad in the book I am currently working on. Currently the book has solutions implemented in traditional OO and Moo only. I would definitely add the Object::Pad in the second revision soon after, promise.

Do you have any story to share with regard to Object::Pad? If yes then please do share with us. Or if you haven't tried it then why not give it a go and make over your existing project to use Object::Pad.

Last but not the least, did you attend The Raku Conference? If not then you can still watch the recordings of the 3 days event. I also gave a short talk (30 minutes) on Day 3 about "Making of Raku Developer".

Enjoy the school holiday period with your loved ones.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
